author: @jlb8111
text: one of my grandfathers volunteered as a pilot for the "luftwaffe" (3. reich air force) at age 18. I remember him, on multiple occasions, proudly recounting war stories of performing maneuvers that lead english planes to crash somewhere, or bombing enemy military and civilian buildings. He told me about it from a very young age, and it was quite a shock for me when I finally was old enough to make the connection between the Nazis and my Grandfather. My other grandfather, being only 14, was drafted as a "Flakhelfer" (a member of the auxiliary staff of the Luftwaffe) and he never spoke with anything but disdain for the nazis and his military service, he was never proud of what he had to do, never boasted and only talked to me about it until I was much older. Both my grandfathers were strict but loving and very respected by their families and peers, both were never outright racist or antisemitic and originally came from anti-hitler families, but one chose to go to war, justified his crimes with "no one knew Hitler was that bad" and boasted about them openly without shame, while the other reflected on the acts he more or less was forced to do and talked to his grandkids about them to make them understand and beware of fascists. These two ways of dealing with what happened make all the difference in my opinion.

Your question of "what is the point of talking about the individual?" is a good one, without an easy answer. It's tricky to decide what to focus on; do we consider the historical consequences (or lack thereof) of "individual decisions/ideologies," or try to amalgamate these into a broader image of the entire group, and how to we decide how "individual decisions" are affected by the group environment/values etc...

Honestly, i feel like it can become a bit of a shadowplay. With enough background information and historical context, it's possible to justify pretty much any decision a given individual makes as a product of their time and perhaps inevitable/destined... and not that that's even strictly "wrong", but I think it robs us of an opportunity to try to look at our own present situations and our own involvement and potential complicity in cruel systems and historical trends. 

 i think the primary aim of the video, along with attempting to dispel the blanket statement mentioned above, is to show us that in fact the individual views of the soldiers didn't actually end up mattering all that much at the time of the war. In fact, the Wermacht seemed to count on that fact (as he says at 31:08 ). those of us who may claim to hold humanitarian views in today's strange and turbulent times might do well to heed that lesson.

@epicgamer-hf4jb Multiple times. It just happens that its ultimate conclusions are far from complete; which is why I wrote this comment "The Wehrmacht is the rough equivalent to the Red army. Both committed w*r crimes but we are not talking about a majority of the enlisted fighters. And ultimately, both served pretty messed up regimes, one clearly far more immoral than the other but people really should stop trying to turn questions about people into questions of institutions.

The myth of the clean Wehrmacht which is really just a question about Germans ideology and actions during WW2 is actually not really that far off when it claims that the average German, in a country with no free press, massive propaganda and often far away from the front, had little idea what exactly happened with the "relocated" people who were brought to the KZs or to the civilians & POWs in occupied territories.

The average soldiers themselves were, while not blind, simply not closely involved with most crimes committed by stuff like the military police behind the lines. When this video argues that the collective Wehrmacht passively helped to commit the atrocities, it‚Äôs as true as to argue that a factory worker making rations directly contributed to w*r crimes committed by men who ate his products. 

Capturing soldiers & civilians for instance is not the same as then letting them starve& freeze to death, not even mentioning the power imbalance between even an officer and the logistical decisions happening in distant w*r rooms etc. . While one may lead to the other, the intention is different and shouldn‚Äôt be so willingly intertwined.

The Nzs knew that their actions were outlandish even for their own citizens, so a ton of propaganda tried to hide what was really going on. Arguably, with a lot more success than people may imagine today.

The invasion of the Soviet Union was framed as a massive defensive effort against a beastlike opponent as opposed to the ideological ideas that lead the high command & the general Nzi elite to go through with the war. Trying to intermingle the ideals of a nation's leadership with its citizens is a surefire way to make connections that are far too often only half-truths. 

When we proclaim that the Wehrmacht was fighting for one reason or another, we purposefully limit our observation to the parts of the army which we can clearly categorize. 

Arguing that fighting in the Wehrmacht enabled the w*r behind the lines is therefore like arguing that the universe being conceived is what caused the atrocities in WW2. It‚Äôs very clearly connected but there was no thought-out effort connecting the actions of individual soldiers who fought in a tank platoon or an infantry battalion with the actions of "anti-partisan" operations so to speak. 

The Wehrmacht itself was also not some kind of blob with a hive-mind mentality. Serving in different units could lead to an entirely different experience of the conflict.

This video fails to understand that the question of whether or not the Wehrmacht was totally clean, completely dirty or something in between is not only related to the broader intentions of the people that were in charge of the army. It‚Äôs actually indeed also a question about individual intentions. For if a soldier refuses to carry out an order, he may get shot and he is not the one deciding where he marches etc. - orders are not just some hypothetical concept. They are a reality that is IMPOSSIBLE to ignore when refusal equals punishment and when the information a soldier can access is INCREDIBLY limited. 

Quite frankly, stating that the Wehrmacht as an institution served a highly immoral purpose dehumanizes the fighting soldiers. We can not put people in such a collective solely based on being part of an army where many soldiers would never even see many regions of the war where they were not deployed."

‚Äã@Arcaryon Every single German knew that Jews were being sent off to camps. Every single German also knew that those Jews would never be seen again. The precise goings on were not known (but rumours abounded), but that's not important. They knew that Jews, simply because they were Jews, were being forced out of their homes and sent to concentration camps to slave until they died. Whether you fought at the front, were stationed in some comfortable location, were out at sea, worked a civilian job back home in Germany, you _knew_ this was the case.

You knew that Jews lost their citizenships in 1933, you knew of all the incremental disenfranchisements of the Jews from that point onwards, and you knew about Kristallnacht in 1938 - all before the Jews were being rounded up en masse and sent off to the camps, which you also knew about. You also knew that the wars Germany was fighting were not in defence, but for revenge.

Yes, the war in the East was framed as a necessary war to rid the world of the communist threat, but before that happened there was Poland - and Denmark - and Norway - and Belgium - and the Netherlands - and France - and Britain. And if you were dumb enough to believe you were fighting a "defensive" war against Russia, then you were also firmly believing that Jews were the mortal enemies of the Reich, and deserved everything that was coming to them.

Not a single German above the age of 5 could truthfully plead ignorance. _They knew,_ whether they approved or not.

I have to adress this directly:

*"When this video argues that the collective Wehrmacht passively helped to commit the atrocities, it‚Äôs as true as to argue that a factory worker making rations directly contributed to w*r crimes committed by men who ate his products."*

Or in other words, "to say that the difference between 5 cm and 7 cm is slight is the same as saying the difference between 1 cm and 700 cm is slight". Someone making rations in a factory isn't actually in the Wehrmacht, and is not part of the soldier's culture of the Wehrmacht. The degree to which the soldiers of the Wehrmacht eagerly participated in atrocities is something largely swept under the carpet. In many cases they gladly volunteered. If you were in the armed forces, you knew what you were fighting for.

author: @FinianFhomhair
text:
This is off topic, but it reminds me of a story that I think is worth telling.
A few years ago I went on a short vacation with my stepdad's family. Because we were so many people, we had to share the cars and I ended up driving with my step dads uncle, who was in his 80es at that time. We went through a village and he said that he remembered the village from his childhood, because it was one of the places where he went with the "hitlerjugend" (the Nazi boyscouts). We started talking about that time and he told me how he had experienced the end of the war. He told me, that in the last days of the war, he was 13 years old and through growing up in Nazi Germany, he was a fanatical Nazi trough and trough. He had tried to join the army earlier, but was permitted because of his age. When finally the "Volkssturm" (the armament of children and old people, to defend Germany to the last man) was called out, he finally saw his chance to do his duty and as in his own words "die for Germany if necessary".
So he went to the local Garrison, where they gave him an uniform-Jacket and an army hat and kept him and the other "volunteers" (a lot of them weren't there because of their free will) there. A few days later he was send as a delivery boy to a nearby outpost. He left the garrison in the early in the morning, so he would get there before sunrise. On the way to the outpost, he passed trough the village, where he's been growing up and met the local Baker, who was the only one who was already up so early. The Baker reckond him in his uniform and asked him if he wanted some bread for breakfast. He replied with a yes and followed the Baker in to the bakery. As soon as both were inside, the Baker loked the door, grapped him and pulled him down into the basement. Down there he tied him up and gagged him and kept him down there,  basically kidnapping him. The Baker did tell no one that he was keeping the boy and released him just a week after the war was over (which was basically two weeks after the kidnapping), because he did know that if anybody would found out, he would be executed immediately for undermining war effort. When released my step-dads uncle was furious, that he missed the chance to fight, called the baker a coward, traitor and "saujude"* (pig-jew), but it took him not to long to realize, that this man had probably saved his life.
He would stay in close contact with that until he died some 25 years later and he could never repay him, for what he had done.

After telling me this story, I asked him how he did feel about that time in retrospective and he answered. "... I just cannot comprehend, how you can completely turn a Human into someone like the person I was back then ... Yes I know, I was young and it was not my fault ... Everybody told me that ... But I still can't comprehend... How can put that madness into a person ... It still scares me when I think how it was and still is possible"

So sorry for that long story, but that story has until today a lot of meaning to me, so I though I might share it.

*Annotation: I also asked him later, if he was antisemitic back then and he replied: "Yes of course I was ... nearly Everybody was and I don't mean that as an excuse ... Even though nobody of us had ever in his life met one, we were just to eager to believe all that crap ... Can you believe it ... We had a teacher who teached us in racial science ... After the war he continued his job ... Just with a  different school subject ... He was only fired years later, because he beat one kid bloody in the 70es [flogging was abolished in 1973], until his dead he was a full blown Nazi, but nobody did give a damn."

@sptony2718 It's quite interesting to hear from your experiences as mine differ considerably. 
I wasn't draftet but joined voluntarily, however that was in 2019, after the Bundeswehr undwerwent some changes in 2017. 
The barracks from basic training was an old Wehrmacht barracks however the only way you knew that was from a plaquette at the entry that listed all units, including American troops, that were stationed there. 
We also had a mural on the wall, but ours was of to modern Bundeswehr soldiers helping each other with a quote that said something to the effect of "Part of comradeship is accepting and defending differing worldviews from your own."
We had one trainee who apparently shared some nazi memes or so in a WhatsApp group and accordingly was removed from training within 2 days, he never even got to wear the uniform. 
All the other trainees in my platoon came from  a wide variety of backgrounds, a lot were women, some had migration backgrounds feom all over the world and almost all Bundesl√§nder were representet. The only thing that they had in common was that we were all rather young, none was older than 25 and except for the one that was discharged in the beginning none had any unusal political views. 

That propably was partially because of my branch as we were in a medical unit, but even later on in other bases i never encountered someone who was a political extremist. 

We also never sang any marching songs, wich I thought was a shame because it certainly would have helped on long marches but I also understand the controversy arround some. 

Ultimately I experienced the average soldier not as someone who saw themself in the tradition of the Wehrmacht but rather a young person that wanted to serve their country. 
That is not to say that there are no bad examples, however I think that the  Bundeswehr has changed a lot in recent years and the old image of it as some kind of far right club neither holds up nor is it helpfull in recruiting responsible, democratic citizen into the ranks.

@leergut858 no. There are, just speaking about the sub group of Verbindungen called "Burschenschaft", many different ones. Ranging from far right to even far left. Generally speaking those belonging to the "Deutsche Burschenschaft" (ein Dachverband) are on the right to far right. Then there are two other large groups who are right to center and then some who are on their own who can be anything from far right to far left.

Then there are the other kinds of Verbindungen. As mentioned in this comment section many of which are Christian. There are the Catholic and protestant ones, and them some that accept members of either faith and sometimes even non Christians. Then there are Corps which take their name from the military unit and predate Burschenschaften by quite some time. To generalise them. They are snobs, but usually have a centris political view (but are overall a political in organisation) and many of them resisted the Nazis and integration into the nazi regime. Then there are the so called Landsmanschaften und Turnerschaften. They are also quite old and a political. Their main purpose is the keeping of tradition, education of their members in a large area of history as well as sports (as implied by the name).

Beyond that you have S√§ngerdchaften( similar to Landsmanaschaften but with a focus on singing in a choir), VDSt literally "fraternity of German students" who's aim is to political educate their members. They are usually Liberal, left or centrist and despise the far right or even the center right. 
After that we have ATB fraternities who's single members go by ATV or similar. They focus on sports and more American style fraternity parties and are also a mostly gender mixed bunch (note: most of the ones I named before only accept male members, with some outliners) 
And last but not least we have ADV or DV or akademische Damenverbibdung. This bunch can not be categorised as their main aim is to be a fraternity for women and theyr aims beyond that differ. They are also mostly less than 10 years old, though some are 60+ years.

This of course means that the true purpose for going against that argument is to enable united and justified violence against the entirety of 'X,' which is a very effective strategy if you intended it to be that way. It's framed as though rejecting the "Not all X are bad" argument will stop group 'X' from attempting to justify their actions, when in actuality you're simply justifying the use of those exact same actions against them. In somewhat insane irony, rejecting the argument actually enables your soldiers to commit terrible actions against the opposition.

Tribunes were civil magistrates in ancient Rome, the term meaning "representative of the tribus" (a tribus was an organized community, the term "tribe" comes from there). Being judged by a tribune meant to be judged by someone acting on behalf of his (and likely yours) community, someone whose authority it was agreed to respect. Paraphrasing a Vietnam veteran volunteered for the service (Army) knowing that he‚Äôd probably wind up over there, almost nobody joined with a conscious desire to commit mayhem. There‚Äôs no ‚ÄúSend me to war so I can be evil! Bazinga!‚Äù
I served with the 18th Airborne Corps in the Gulf War. Virtually every other enlisted man I knew was there because (1) they needed a job, (2) didn‚Äôt want to go to college, (3) joined for access to the GI Bill or (4) were fleeing some fairly serious home situations and the military was an escape. Most of the guys who decided to stay in decided they would be better off in uniform that going back home and starting over. Nobody wanted to ‚Äúbe Audie Murphy,‚Äù or had any serious thoughts about killing anyone until they (we) found ourselves facing actual combat deployment. By the way, even Audie Murphy didn‚Äôt join the military looking to be a hero. He was the oldest son in his family, his father abandoned them and he quit school to help his mother provide for younger siblings. When his mom became fatally ill, he went into the service in order to have money to send to relatives who took his siblings in. Because of his size (five feet five, 120lbs ‚Äúsoaking wet‚Äù), the Navy and the Marines refused to induct him and his commander in the 3rd Infantry Division wanted to discharge him before deployment because they just didn‚Äôt think he could physically ‚Äúhack it‚Äù in combat. The point is, he was there for basic ‚Äúbread and butter‚Äù family reasons‚Ä¶just like a LOT of others who have since served in Korea, Vietnam, Iraq (either time) and Afghanistan. Just saying.

text:
The Wehrmacht not only quantitatively committed more war crimes than their Allied counterparts but also, and this can not be emphasized enough, the way they waged war during WWII was criminal from the outset as a matter of institutional policy. And not just in the way that the IMT in N√ºrnberg found that they were guilty of waging a war of aggression but the very way how they fought and what forms of warfare they encouraged was steeped in Nazi ideology.

This started from the very beginning of the war when the attack on Gleiwitz was faked in order to produce a casus belli against Poland, to the regular collaboration of the Wehrmacht with the SS and Einsatzgruppen in Poland, to the attack on neutral countries in the Benelux, to the blatant disregard to the laws of war in France where e.g. Rommel both used tactics such as setting civilians' houses on fire in order to mask his troops' advance to feigning surrender in order to draw French troops in, to the anti-Partisan operations in the Balkans, to the war against the Soviet Union being planned as a war of annihilation and thus constituting a war crime in itself, down to the lowest level of the units where massive violence against civilians and their property was encouraged as a tactic of warfare on a massive level.

The Wehrmacht as an institution superseded the "normal" function of an army within your average nation state  and crossed the territory into becoming an institution heavily involved and complicit in the crimes of the Nazi state.

This came to bear in that the Wehrmacht and especially its higher echelons were by the time of the attack on the Soviet Union thoroughly "nazified". The war against the Soviets was in their mind not a "normal" war but a war of annihilation. Meaning that civilians as well as the soldiers of the other side were perceived as such an existential thread that extreme violence and terror were the only appropriate measure in dealing with them.

It doesn't come as a great shock then that new research by S√∂nke Neitzel and Harald Welzer as well as Felix R√∂mer based on newly discovered eve's dropping protocols from British and American POW camps shows that within the Wehrmacht a vast majority of soldiers considered violence against civilians, even women and children in some cases, as a legitimate form of warfare, especially when justified with Partisan warfare. Examples of this, specifically referenced by the Wehrmacht soldiers themselves, include using women and children to clear mine fields; burning down buildings with the inhabitants inside; and the use of public hangings in order to deter support for real or imagined Partisan groups.

The frequency of such happenings as well as the level of involvement on part of the individual soldier are hard to gauge but from all research up to date, it is possible to conclude that almost every unit involved in the war in the Soviet Union or the Balkans did commit atrocities in one form or another on regular basis. Similarly, it is hard to number the victims of Wehrmacht atrocities but even discounting the starved Soviet POWs the number of civilian murdered by the Wehrmacht runs in the several millions.

You rightfully say at the end of the video, that we cannot assume, that with the end of WW2 and the punishment of the nazi leaders, german society was suddenly cleansed off nazi ideology. 

I would go a bit further: We cannot assume, that nazi ideology has ever been an actually integral part of german society to begin with:  We are talking about people who lived in the monarchy of the Kaiserreich first, than in the Weimarer Republik, then in the dictatorship of the nazis and then either in the BRD or the DDR (and some first in the DDR and then in the BRD). Under all of these regimes they were just ordinary, decent citizens, trying to live ordinary and decent lives. They changed there apparent beliefs just as the system of government changed. If they would have had any actual ideological beliefs, at least a sizeable amount would have wanted to return to the Kaiserreich etc., there would have been resistances trying to restore the former way of government. But that was scarcely the case, because most people don't care for ideology.

Now that may sound like some sort oft apology at first glance: Most germans were never actually convinced nazis, not even when they elected and supported the nazis. But what it actually means is that such people would just follow any ideology as long as in doing so they would secure their own standing in that society. It makes their behaviour not less evil, it merely makes their evil a trivial thing, grounded not in evil convictions, but in a lack of any conviction at all - and therefore also a lack of any moral principle. It is wrong to emphasize ideology, because by removing some evil ideology you don't make people morally better. They usually don't really care for that ideology in the first place. And if, in order to live such a life, you have to turn a blind eye against the murder of millions of jews, or the deaths of hundreds of thousends of refugees drowning in the mediterranian, well then most people do just that. The evil here is not antisemitism or racism or whatever ideology you might come up with, but indifference and lazyness. Some diehard nazis driven by hatred against jews won't be able to do much. Millions of indifferent decent citizens however provide the condition for these crimes to take place, not because of malevolence or hatred or some sadistic urge to murder and destroy, but the trivial wish to fit in and to not take any responsibility. So we don't need to argue against evil ideology. But we need to teach people take responsibility. The ideological betterment will then follow anyway.

author: @fuzzydunlop7928
text:
I think this issue is one of the reasons Johannes Blaskowitz is a figure that deserves more research and attention. He‚Äôs a promising general who - after leading the 8th army in the invasion of Poland - is given the title of Commander in Chief of Poland. During that time, he not only writes voraciously protesting the harsh treatment of Jews and Poles but even sentences SS men to death for carrying out such crimes. He‚Äôs probably the highest-ranking German commander to resist the Nazi leadership on something that wasn‚Äôt an affront to his or the OKH‚Äôs sense of authority.

Well, he‚Äôs mocked by Hitler for his ‚ÄúSalvation Army attitude‚Äù and removed from command and position (and those death sentences are never carried out, Himmler intervenes) - as opposed to just ‚Äúbeing shot‚Äù as other German generals insisted would‚Äôve happened had they raised serious concern. He‚Äôs sent to the German equivalent of Burma, the front where you send misfits you want out of the way, eventually taking charge of part of Northern France at some point. According to author Christopher Clark, Blaskowitz attempted to do in France what he was he was blocked from doing in Poland and conduct a ‚Äòhearts and minds‚Äô-centric occupation, but the French had already experienced massacres and harsh measures and were having fucking none of it and walking the line of fighting an insurgency effectively, enforcing measures dictated from higher up, and trying to win the acquiescence of the locals proved untenable. 

Anyway, here‚Äôs the kicker, later in the war, Blaskowitz - who so adamantly protested the actions going on in Poland and who knows to some degree what must be going on in the Soviet theater (enough to reportedly try and convince Rommel anyway) - goes BACK when Hitler beckons him with an army command - Army group G. Not only does he go back but after the July coup attempt Blaskowitz sends to Hitler a personal letter professing his utter loyalty. I believe only two German generals of this senior level never served on the Soviet front - Blaskowitz and this utterly-irrelevant midget tax-evader named Erwin Rommel, but I could be wrong. 

Anyway, Blaskowitz commands army group G for a while and eventually ends up in charge of the still-occupied parts of the Netherlands (or maybe just Holland) during the ‚Äòhungerwinter‚Äô - the period of starvation that occurred there late in the war. He makes an agreement with the allied commanders that if they don‚Äôt bomb German positions he wont fire on their airlifts of food supplies to the Dutch civilians. He may or may not have gone against orders to do this, I‚Äôm not really sure. 

Well, the war eventually ends and ole‚Äô Blaskowitz is indicted at the Nuremberg trials which actually makes sense - I mean, look at his commands - Occupation of Poland, Occupation of France, Occupation of Holland during a famine. At face value it was probably safe to assume he had some dirt on his jacket, however, after an investigation is carried out he‚Äôs supposedly informed by his lawyer that he‚Äôs going to be acquitted of all the charges. 

Blaskowitz promptly plunges off a balcony to his death, which is ruled a suicide - befuddling historians and conspiracy theorists ever since. His fellow prisoners said he was murdered by the SS to prevent him from providing information on their activities in Poland - Blaskowitz big ‚Äòact of resistance‚Äô from earlier in the war. Here‚Äôs the thing - the fucking idiots in charge of the Nuremberg trials enlisted former SS men - Hiwis - to act as guards. That gives the theory some bite and I don‚Äôt for a minute consider Blasko the type to kill himself, firstly he had YEARS to off himself during and after the war if he felt so guilty - secondly - he probably didn‚Äôt feel guilty which brings me to my goal in bringing him up. 

The Blaskowitz story is pretty sad (in say the British or American or even Italian armies, he probably would‚Äôve risen to a high rank and been a decent guy by the low low standards of generals), but he‚Äôs not a hero or a martyr and that‚Äôs the whole point. Blaskowitz not only shows that German generals could voice opposition without execution (they simply only chose to resist when their authority was undermined on strategic matters) but that despite ALL of the things Blaskowitz did to make his little pocket of hell a little less hellish, he was still a willing cog in the murder machine who justified his position, because of his position - as a soldier he went along with it all despite knowing a decent amount about what was going on. 

Still, there is a tremendous amount of humanity to Blaskowitz. His story begs the question, what would you do in his situation? How much can you justify or reconcile? Blaskowitz was not an evil man and he didn‚Äôt have to be the devil,, but he was middle-management all the same. It also gives a glimpse into the psyche of the commander‚Äôs ‚Äúends justify the means‚Äù mindset, the command-blinders. Blaskowitz could‚Äôve been any American general in the Vietnam war.

author: @sammiller4735
text:
One of the main reasons why there's this image of the "clean wehrmacht" is simply because of how little they were punished after the war, which you mentioned with the statements and actions of Eisenhower and Adenauer. Not to get like, too into this and just ramble in your comments, but I think its important to really note why America and West Germany were so lenient on the Wehrmacht; they needed soldiers to stand opposed to the Soviet Union! When you get down to it, for the American occupiers the USSR and socialism in general was a much bigger threat ideologically, economically, politically than remnant Nazism. That's why America did all in its power to electorally weaken the SPD in postwar Germany even though SoPaDe, the exile SPD organization, was supported by the British. And that is ultimately why a Wehrmacht general, Hans Speidel, ended up becoming Supreme Commander of NATO ground forces in central Europe. I think the ethos of the time was put best by mercenary and former Wehrmacht soldier Siegfried M√ºller who, in an interview in 1966, described himself as fighting for the values of Western Civilization when he was committing atrocities in the Congo in service of Belgium and the United States in fighting the supporters of Congolese PM Patrice Lumumba. For the Wehrmacht soldier in the post-war world, their worldview barely had to change; their enemies were still the communists that Hitler railed against for years, just now they were on a different payroll.

I actually think a much more fascinating example of denazification is the role of former Wehrmacht soldiers in the German Democratic Republic, mostly just because its much more complicated than what they ended up doing in postwar West Germany and elsewhere. The Soviet Union wasn't interested in co-opting former Nazis like America was, but East Germany did still deal with the large presence of Wehrmacht soldiers in a unique way. There was a political party called the National Democratic Party which was formed and encouraged by communist politician Lothar Bolz to transition former NSDAP members and Wehrmacht soldiers into postwar politics. I will admit I'm not an expert on it by any means, and I still think that there is a lot to criticize in the postwar restructuring of German society in the East, but at the very least they didn't just give former Wehrmacht soldiers high positions or jobs fighting in proxy conflicts /shrug.

Sorry for the rambling response btw it was just some stuff I was thinking of as I was watching this! Fantastic video by the way!

tl;dr: the reason why Eisenhower and Adenauer were lenient on the Wehrmacht and eventually the Waffen-SS is because they shared an enemy in socialism and could co-opt the Nazi military to Cold War ends.

author: @mattgilbert7347
text:
Exceptional work. 
I wonder about the extent of sympathetic feeling towards the German & Italian sides among the Allied armed forces. I'll never forget how my father, a Northern Irishman who was in the Royal Engineers in Sicily, Italy, and Austria, told me that, while he was "a kind of Socialist", something I already knew, he was also "a Fascist". 

He admired Mussolini, and when he was in the army of occupation in Austria, serving on ordinance-finding & removal duties, applied to marry a local, Austrian girl. I'm not sure of the extent of her support for the fash, but my grandfather's telegram back to Dad (he asked permission to marry, first to his CO, then forwarded back home) was... interesting. "Not having son of mine marry one of enemy"

I assume it also read:
"STOP"üòÇ

Onya, Grandad. No offense to the fine womenfolk of Austria. 

Dad was definitely impressed by Fascism, although I think his lifelong love of Italian Opera and Austrian food (weekends at the Austrian Cafe in Christchurch NZ, fun times...not) was basically innocent..he just liked the food and the music. 

But he also liked the politics.

He thought the Nazis were kind of a joke tho. A dangerous joke. Didn't go in for hardline racism. Just the casual stuff typical to a white man of his generation. 

He tended to fetishise power and strength. That was, i think, the root of it. Maybe the Catholicism also played a role, hard to say. It certainly tracks with the "corporate populist" variety of Fascism he seemed to identify with.
